controversies: 2015 lawsuit by the Ecological Rights Foundation for environmental violations
2019 derivative lawsuit revealing $338 million in concealed cost overruns
environmental_issues: Failure to control stormwater runoff at a Santa Cruz County quarry, violating the U.S. Clean Water Act
social_issues: Workplace safety violations, including failure to medically evaluate employees required to use respirators
Labor shortages exacerbating project delays and increasing costs
governance_issues: Revenue recognition under ASC Topic 606 relying heavily on estimates of project costs and timelines, increasing risk of financial misstatements

sources.title: Granite Construction's history of environmental violations
sources.snippet: California:2015 -> The Ecological Rights Foundation accused Granite Construction Co in a June 2015 lawsuit of failing to maintain controls over stormwater runoff at a Santa Cruz County quarry in violation of the U.S. Clean Water Act and a permit. Granite agreed to a settlement with ERF in May 2016. Vew Source

sources.title: Granite Construction Disputes but Settles Lawsuit to Avoid Protracted ...
sources.snippet: WATSONVILLE, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- Granite Construction Incorporated (NYSE:GVA) announced today that its subsidiary, Granite Construction Company, has entered into a settlement to end a civil lawsuit with the City of San Diego related to a 2007 debris removal contract. Granite has agreed to pay the City a total of $400,000 to dismiss the suit and admits no wrongdoing as part of the settlement.

sources.title: Granite Construction Inc. (NYSE:GVA): Paving the Way for a Better ...
sources.snippet: There has been a turnaround in the business ever since Kyle Larkin became CEO in 2021. Prior to 2021, it was highly mismanaged. The firm used to bid on large projects that were met with delays and cost overruns. It also came under the radar of the SEC due to account fraud. The focus is now on smaller projects with a size of $5 million.
